body.p: To his Excellency Thos. E. Bramlette Governor of Kentucky:

Your petitioner John B. Cumming would respectfully represent to your Excellency that at the present August Term of the Clinton Circuit Court he has confessed judgment on three Indictments found against him in said, one for keeping a Tipling house; the judgment being Sixty dollars and the other Indictments being for selling to soldiers within five miles of a Camp the judgment being ten dollars in each case. He further represents that at the time he sold spirituous liquors in Albany there was no authorities from whom he could procure License, that Civil Authority had been and was Suspended in Clinton County and the County was then under military protection and rule, that he only sold for the period of about two weeks in last February, that he did not know that he was guilty of violating any law, that he did not know that he was doing any wrong, & that he has been a law abiding peaceful citizen.
He now respectfully petitions your Excellency to remit said fines and he promises that in the future he will be more cautious and will try and keep in the bounds of the law.
Sworn to before me by John B Cummings this 29th day of August 1865. P H Hopkins P J C C C

To his Excellency Thos E. Bramlette
Governor of Kentucky:

We would respectfully state that it is true as represented by Mr Cummings that their was no authority in Albany or Clinton County vested with Authority to grant tipling or liquor licenses and that so far as we know his other statements are true.

We would, therefore, in view of all the Circumstances, respectfully petition your Excellency to remit said fines.
Albany, Ky.
August 29th 1865

Wm Vann
C P Gray
W A Russell
H. H. Hurt
J A Brents
John W, S, Brooks

Clinton Cir Ct
vs
John B Cummins
3 judgts
One for $60,
two for $10. each
Remitted 16 Sept 1865
Sent for fee 5 Sept to Monticello
